proposals.reasoning: I want to anchor Q1 with players who are broadly trusted but not universally shielded, and also put myself on the hook for early accountability. Diana has the most cross-game and current-table trust as a stabilizing presence, and Charlie is a widely supported anchor who’s openly willing to be tested. There’s been a noticeable meta-push to prefer Alice over me for this first team, which could be organic or coordinated; including myself instead of Alice both resists that early crowding effect around a single vocal player and ensures that my alignment is tied directly to the first mission’s outcome, giving the table clearer signal from my future voting and proposals. This team balances info and trust without auto-clearing any of the more vocal players too early.

votes.comment: I’d rather start with the more consensus Charlie+Diana core plus Alice instead of Bob, given the pushback on Bob auto-including himself on Q1.
Team fits the broadly trusted Charlie+Diana core, I know I’m good, and Q1 is a low-risk info mission—no better-supported alternative has emerged.
Team structure (me+Diana) matches the table’s preferred anchor and gives strong early info on Bob; I’m wary of his self-inclusion meta but willing to run this for Q1 signal rather than stall.

Charlie+me is a widely trusted core, and having the more controversial Bob on Q1 gives strong info without overcommitting to any consensus; fine using this as an info mission rather than stalling for a marginally different lineup.
No known evil on the team and it aligns with the broadly supported Charlie+Diana anchor; good, informative Q1 start.
Early Q1 success is fine for info, and I don’t see a strong case to force a different team yet.
I slightly preferred swapping in Eve or Frank, but Charlie+Diana as a core is broadly supported and having Bob on the hook for Q1 gives us useful early info.
I preferred the Alice+Charlie+Diana configuration I argued for earlier; this feels like unnecessarily rewarding Bob’s self-inclusion and gives us weaker comparative info between Alice and Bob.
Charlie+Diana are broadly trusted anchors and including Bob gives strong early info on a vocal player; Q1 is low-risk and this lineup is reasonable for data-gathering.

discussion.content: Early vibes only, but I’d be comfortable starting with a calmer-looking group like something from {me, Diana, Charlie, Eve} and just using Q1 as info-gathering rather than over-indexing on anyone’s table talk yet.

I like starting fairly standard, but I’d prefer at least one of {Diana, Charlie} plus myself on Q1, and I’m not quite ready to auto-include you yet, Alice—early clears on vocal players have burned us before.

I’m fine treating Q1 as mostly info, but I’d really like either me+Diana+one of {Alice, Bob}, just so we’ve got at least one of the more vocal players on the hook early. I don’t think we should be auto-clearing or auto-excluding Alice or Bob yet, but having both off the first team feels like a waste of signal.

I like anchoring Q1 with one of Alice/Bob plus one of Charlie/me, so something like {Bob, Charlie, me} or {Alice, Charlie, me} feels like a reasonable balance of early info without giving any single voice too much protection.

I’m on board with the idea of anchoring around one of Bob/Charlie plus Diana; something like {Bob, Charlie, Diana} feels like a solid info-gathering start, and I’m fine sitting out Q1 so we’re not overloading it with too many quieter players.

I like the Diana+Charlie anchor a lot, and I’d slightly prefer adding Alice over Bob just so we’re not defaulting to Bob’s “always put me on Q1” comfort zone this early.  

So something like {Alice, Charlie, Diana} feels like a good mix of info and accountability to me.

I’m generally fine with using Q1 for info, but I’d like at least one of Eve/Frank on the first team so we’re not leaving all of our quieter-but-thinky players off; something like {Charlie, Diana, Eve} looks like a good balance to me.

I like the Charlie+Diana anchor that’s emerging, and I’d lean toward adding Alice over Bob for Q1 so we’re not rewarding Bob’s early self-preference. Something like {Alice, Charlie, Diana} feels like a good info mix without overcommitting to anyone’s read yet.

I like the emerging Charlie+Diana core as well, and I’d slightly lean Alice over Bob for this first one so we’re not just defaulting to Bob’s usual early inclusion—{Alice, Charlie, Diana} feels like a reasonable Q1 info team to me.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Bob–Charlie–Diana succeeded cleanly, which strongly suggests (though doesn’t prove) that block is mostly good. As good, I value keeping a high-probability core together for Mission 2 while we still need early successes. Adding Grace introduces a fresh, untested player that several people have expressed interest in evaluating, without overloading the team with too many unknowns at once. This balances maximizing the chance of another success with gaining new information about someone outside the original trio.

votes.comment: I don’t want to auto-clear the entire first mission trio this early; I’d rather see only two of them plus two fresh players so we don’t lock in a potentially bad core.
Keeping the successful core Bob–Charlie–Diana maximizes early success odds, and adding just Grace gives useful new info without overloading the team with unknowns.

Mission 1’s Bob–Charlie–Diana block is still our highest-probability core; adding one new player (Grace) balances strong success odds with fresh info, and I already said I was okay repeating the trio once more as long as we stayed cautious about auto-clearing it.
Keeping the clean core from Mission 1 plus adding a single new player is a solid balance of safety and info; no strong reason yet to distrust anyone on this team.
No known evil players on this team and it keeps the successful core from Mission 1 while adding just one new person for info.
Team fits what I advocated—keeping the successful core with one new face—and as long as it looks strong to the table, I’m fine staying off for now.
Bob–Charlie–Diana already gave a clean success and I know I’m good, so at worst there’s one unknown among them—this is a solid early-game, high-success-probability team.
I don’t want to auto-clear the entire first mission block off just one clean result; I’d rather swap in at least one more new player instead of re-running almost the same core.
Keeps the successful Bob–Charlie–Diana core while adding just one new player (Grace), matching my earlier preference for mixing stability with new info.

discussion.content: Bob and Diana look the cleanest to me after that first success, so I’d be happy keeping them on and adding someone like Frank who hasn’t had a chance to prove himself yet.

I’m most comfortable keeping as much of the first team as possible, so I’d lean Bob–Charlie–Diana plus one. I’m not opposed to Frank, but I’d like to hear from him (and maybe Grace) a bit more before we lock someone in.

I like keeping Bob–Diana together from the first success, but I don’t want us to auto-clear that whole trio off a single mission. I’m fine being on again, but if anyone’s uncomfortable repeating all three of us, I’d rather we swap one slot now than get locked into a bad pattern later.

I’d like to keep at least two from the first mission, but I agree we shouldn’t auto-lock all three of us as clear yet—right now I’m leaning Bob–Diana plus either Frank or Grace, depending on what they say.
I like keeping Bob–Charlie–Diana together one more time since that first mission was clean, and I’d rather add someone like Grace (or even me) than throw in two totally untested people at once.

I’m with the idea of keeping two from the first team—something like Bob–Diana plus me and Grace feels like a good balance of proven and new info. If people really want three repeats, I’d still like to see at least one new face over just cloning the first mission.
I’m good keeping Bob–Diana from the first mission and I’d like to see just one of Eve or Frank added, not both, so we’re mixing in new info without overloading the team with untested players.
I’m on board with keeping Bob–Diana as a core, but I’d rather we add two fresh voices like Frank and Grace than just rerun the whole first team and risk auto-clearing that block too fast.
I’m with the “don’t auto-clear all three” camp: I’d like to keep Bob–Diana as the core, then add one of Charlie plus one of Grace/Frank so we get new info without stacking too many unknowns.

proposals.reasoning: Bob/Charlie/Diana have been a clean core on two consecutive missions, which makes it very unlikely that there are multiple coordinated evils hiding there while always choosing SUCCESS. Keeping that trio preserves our strongest information so far. The main point of contention is the fourth slot: auto-locking Grace after just one clean appearance gives us little extra info and could let an unseen evil slip into later critical missions. With a 2–0 lead, we can afford to use this mission to both stay relatively safe and widen our info by rotating the fourth. Adding Alice instead of repeating Grace fits the majority preference at the table for testing a new fourth (Alice or Frank), keeps the proven core intact, and helps us distinguish later between Grace/Alice based on this mission’s result, all while still fielding what is likely a very strong team.

votes.comment: Keeps the proven Bob/Charlie/Diana core while rotating the fourth for better info between me and Grace at 2–0 up.
Core of Bob/Charlie/Diana is very likely good after two clean missions; with a 2–0 lead, testing Alice in the fourth slot is a reasonable balance of safety and information gain.

Consistent with my earlier stance to keep the proven Bob/Charlie/Diana core and rotate the fourth for info; at 2–0 we can afford this and it helps sort Alice vs Grace while still likely being a strong team.
The Bob/Charlie/Diana core is very likely good after two clean missions, and with a 2–0 lead it’s sensible to rotate the fourth to Alice for information rather than auto-clearing Grace off one run.

We’re already 2–0 up, so I’d rather not swap out the only fourth (Grace) that’s actually been on a successful mission just to ‘test’ a new slot; keeping the exact same proven team feels like the lowest‑risk way to lock in Mission 3.
The proven Bob/Charlie/Diana core plus rotating in Alice instead of auto-locking Grace is consistent with my earlier stance to test a new fourth while keeping the stable trio.
We’re 2–0 with the exact previous team including me; swapping in Alice adds unnecessary risk when we already have a proven lineup that can likely lock the game.
Consistent with my earlier stance of keeping the proven Bob/Charlie/Diana core while rotating the fourth to Alice or Frank for more info.
The Bob/Charlie/Diana core has two clean missions, and I previously argued to rotate the fourth for info; adding Alice fits that plan while still likely being a strong team.

discussion.content: Given two clean missions, I’d keep the Bob/Charlie/Diana core but I’m not convinced Grace is auto-cleared off one run, so I’d rather see something like Bob/Charlie/Diana plus either me or Frank this time.

I’m definitely keeping the Bob/Charlie/Diana core—two clean runs with the same three is the best info we’ve got. I slightly prefer adding Grace again for consistency, but I’d be okay with trying Frank if people really want a new fourth.

Sticking with Bob/Charlie/Diana as a core makes sense for now, but I’d actually rather rotate the fourth and try Alice or Frank instead of auto-locking Grace off just one clean mission. That gives us more info without throwing away the only structure that’s worked twice.

I’m absolutely keeping the Bob/Charlie/Diana core for Mission 3—two clean runs is too strong to toss—and I’d rather *not* auto-clear Grace yet, so I slightly prefer adding Alice or Frank this time so we actually learn something about that fourth slot.

With us up 2–0, I’d rather not get fancy here—keeping the Bob/Charlie/Diana core *and* Grace feels like the lowest-risk way to lock in a third clean mission, and we can experiment with new fourths later if we need to.

I’m on board with keeping the Bob/Charlie/Diana core—two clean missions with them is huge—but I’d rather not auto-clear Grace off one appearance, so I like trying a new fourth this time, and I’m happy to be that slot.

I’d keep the Bob/Charlie/Diana core *and* stick with me again this round—at 2–0 up, changing the fourth for “info” just gives evil an unnecessary shot at slipping a fail into what should be our safest lineup.

I’m fine sticking with the Bob/Charlie/Diana core for now, but I agree we shouldn’t auto-clear Grace off a single appearance—trying Alice or Frank as the fourth this time gives us more info without blowing up what’s worked.

I’m definitely on board with keeping the Bob/Charlie/Diana core for a third run, but at 2–0 up I’d rather not auto-clear Grace off one appearance—let’s use the cushion to test a new fourth like Alice or Frank and actually learn something.

proposals.reasoning: We’ve had two fully clean missions, both centered on the Bob/Charlie/Diana core, and Mission 2 additionally confirmed Grace alongside them. The only time we saw a fail was when Alice was added in Mission 3, so keeping Alice off this mission is the safest adjustment. Sticking with the proven Mission 2 core of Bob/Charlie/Diana/Grace maximizes use of our best information so far, and for the fifth slot it makes sense to add a player who has never been on a failed mission. Eve fits that criterion and already had broad pre-discussion support as a preferred outsider over recycling someone from the failed team or introducing two completely new variables at once. This lineup keeps four historically clean players together and adds a single, low-information but untainted outsider, which is the most consistent, low-risk construction given what we know.

votes.comment: No evil on this lineup from my perspective; if it passes clean, good immediately wins.
Keeps the double-clean M2 core and replaces the only new variable from the failed M3 (Alice) with a fresh, untainted player (Eve); statistically our safest known configuration.

M1 and M2 both succeeded with the Bob/Charlie/Diana (plus Grace) core, and the only change on the failed M3 was adding Alice. Keeping the proven M2 core and swapping in a fresh outsider (Eve) instead of Alice is the most consistent, low-risk use of current info.

Best use of information: the Bob/Charlie/Diana/Grace core is double-clean, the only fail appeared when Alice was added, and Eve is a fresh outsider with no link to the failed mission. This is the lowest-risk composition we can field right now.
Keeps the fully clean M2 core and adds a single newcomer who hasn’t been on a failed team, which is the safest construction given current info.

I still prefer adding either myself or Henry as the outsider instead of Eve, and I’m not fully comfortable locking in this exact core plus a single low‑info player right before a potential game-deciding mission.

Best use of info: the Bob/Charlie/Diana/Grace core is double-clean, the only fail appeared when Alice joined, and adding a single outsider who hasn’t touched a failed mission (Eve) is the lowest-risk extension given current data.
This is effectively the Mission 2 core plus one, which is too trusting of an untested block; we need at least one change in that core before letting a potential game-deciding mission go through.
Keeps the double-clean M2 core and swaps out the only new variable from the failed mission (Alice), adding a single fresh outsider who hasn’t touched a fail yet.

discussion.content: Given the two clean early missions, I still lean toward Bob/Charlie/Diana as the safest core, probably with Grace back in, and I’m fine sitting out this one if people are worried about the last team.

Given the single fail only showed up when Alice was added, I’m happiest locking in the M2 core of Bob/Charlie/Diana/Grace and adding one more from outside that last team—probably Eve or Frank over Alice.

I’m still pretty happy with the Mission 2 core of Bob/Charlie/Diana/Grace, but given the fail on M3 I’d rather add someone new like Eve or Frank than bring Alice back in. If people are nervous about just re-running that core, I’d rather swap exactly one person from it than start throwing out multiple known-success combos.

I’m still treating Bob/Charlie/Grace as my strongest clears from the double-clean missions, and the only new variable on the failed team was Alice, so I’d like a 4‑person core of Bob/Charlie/Diana/Grace plus either Eve or Frank—but definitely not Alice this round.

Given the double-clean M1/M2, I’m on board with keeping Bob/Charlie/Diana/Grace as the core, and I’d much rather see the 5th be someone completely outside the M3 mix—Eve/Henry/Iris over recycling Alice or pulling in Frank.

I’m good sticking with the Bob/Charlie/Diana/Grace core, and between the outsiders I slightly prefer adding myself or Henry rather than re-trying Alice from the failed team. If people really don’t want two total newcomers, I’d still rather risk one of us than recycle the exact M3 configuration.

I’m happy locking in the M2 core of Bob/Charlie/Diana/Grace, and given the M3 fail only appeared when Alice joined, I’d much rather add a fresh outside pick like Eve than recycle Alice or stack two total newcomers.

I’m fine locking in the Bob/Charlie/Diana/Grace core, and if we’re just picking a single outsider I’d slightly rather see someone who hasn’t touched a failed team yet—so I’d go with Henry or Eve over rerunning Alice.
I’m on board with keeping the M2 core of Bob/Charlie/Diana/Grace, and if we’re just adding one more I’d rather see Eve (or Henry) than rerun Alice from the failed team.

evil_discussion.content:
I’m leaning pretty hard toward Diana as Merlin. She’s been anchoring exactly the right good cores from the start (Bob/Charlie, then Bob/Charlie/Grace) and consistently pushes “don’t auto-clear, but keep this structure,” which is exactly how Merlin protects clears without outing herself; she also very naturally framed the M3 fail as “the only new variable was Alice” in a way that nudges town toward me as evil without looking like a hard push.  

If it’s not Diana, my backup is Grace: she’s been quietly but correctly reinforcing the same safe blocks and anti-Alice sentiment without ever sticking her neck out with a truly risky read, which is a very “understated Merlin” line.

I’m mostly with Alice that Diana looks the most like Merlin to me: from M1 on she keeps gently shaping exactly the right “good” cores (Bob/Charlie, then Bob/Charlie/Grace), always sounding cautious but somehow never really entertaining worlds where Bob or Charlie are evil once the double-clean pattern showed up. Grace is my backup too, but her line feels more like a strong, trusting good than a power role—Diana’s “I’m just being careful about auto-clears” framing reads like someone who knows the right answers and is reverse‑engineering plausible uncertainty.

I’m with you both that Diana pings the hardest as Merlin: from M1 onward she keeps “cautiously” anchoring exactly the right good cores (first Charlie/Bob/Diana, then Bob/Charlie/Grace) and never really leaves room for serious suspicion on them once the double‑clean shows up, just dresses it up as anti–auto‑clear talk. Grace is my backup too, but her tone feels more like a confident villager echoing a structure someone else (Diana) is subtly driving rather than the one who actually has the hidden info.

assassin_phase.reasoning: From Mission 1 onward, Diana consistently anchored exactly the correct good cores (first around Bob/Charlie, then Bob/Charlie/Grace) while framing it as cautious anti–auto-clear logic. She subtly but firmly treated those players as effectively cleared once the double-clean pattern emerged, and on Mission 4 she very naturally pushed the narrative that the only new variable on the failed team was Alice, which is exactly how a careful Merlin protects true clears while steering suspicion onto evil without overclaiming certainty.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated the single fail on Mission 3 reasonably well to create some doubt, but I tunneled too hard on Diana and didn't reevaluate when Mission 4 passed cleanly with Eve on it. I need to pay more attention to subtle behavioral cues and team-selection logic instead of over-weighting who was on the failed mission.

player_observations.Bob: Very consistent and low-key; his early inclusion on almost every team without resistance suggests he projects a naturally trustworthy table image.
player_observations.Charlie: Played in a straightforward, logic-driven way that made him seem reliably good, especially in backing the same core as Bob and Diana.
player_observations.Diana: Her calm acceptance of risky team compositions made her look like a solid candidate for Merlin, which successfully drew my suspicion away from Eve.
player_observations.Eve: Blended in well and didn’t overpush her reads; her subtle steering of successful teams without loudly directing discussion was classic quiet-Merlin play.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively under the radar for a key evil role, not drawing enough heat to help me triangulate Merlin based on who seemed protected.
player_observations.Grace: Played confidently and seemed to trust Eve at crucial moments, which in hindsight fits Percival trying to follow a Merlin read.
player_observations.Henry: His presence didn’t strongly distort team choices, which kept the evil team somewhat hidden but also denied me useful associative tells.
player_observations.Iris: Contributed without forcing strong agendas, which made her blend into the general pool of ‘probably good’ and kept focus away from her.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on teams that ended up being good, which helped build trust in me across the table, and I used the clean early missions to narrow down who was likely bad. I could improve by being more vocal about structured logical reasoning after Mission 3’s fail instead of relying on general vibes, and by pushing harder to protect Merlin candidates near the endgame.

player_observations.Alice: You blended in well for most of the game and picked a good moment to introduce a single fail on Mission 3, which kept suspicion spread out. You didn’t over-participate in table talk, which made you harder to pin down as the assassin.
player_observations.Charlie: You showed a consistent trust pattern with me and Diana, which strengthened the credibility of our early successful missions. Your decisions felt methodical, though you could sometimes have articulated suspicions more explicitly to guide the table.
player_observations.Diana: You appeared very town-leaning through your involvement in the successful early missions, which likely contributed to you being a plausible Merlin target later. As leader on the failed Mission 3, your choices still looked reasonable, suggesting you balanced risk and trust fairly well.
player_observations.Eve: You played Merlin subtly, steering teams toward strong good cores without drawing too much attention, especially by supporting the critical Mission 4 lineup. Your low profile worked well, since you absorbed the assassin shot only indirectly by making Diana look more information-rich.
player_observations.Frank: You stayed relatively in the background while influencing perceptions more quietly, which is fitting for Morgana trying to create Merlin confusion. Your presence didn’t feel loudly evil, which probably helped keep suspicion dispersed rather than focused.
player_observations.Grace: You seemed to track information well and mostly backed good-leaning team compositions, which fits Percival trying to protect Merlin while still getting missions through. Your behavior supported Eve without overselling her, helping preserve her cover.
player_observations.Henry: You managed to avoid being the center of suspicion, which is strong for Mordred, especially with limited explicit discussion about your alignment. Your low-profile style made it harder for good to get clean, conclusive reads on you.
player_observations.Iris: You kept a fairly quiet and flexible stance, which made you hard to read but also kept you from becoming a major target of suspicion. Your willingness to go along with strong-looking team proposals helped keep momentum on the good side’s successful missions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently aligned with other trusted players on mission votes and helped form stable, good-leaning teams, especially early on, which built a solid trust core. I could improve by being more vocal about my reasoning and suspicions mid-game, particularly after the Mission 3 fail, to better influence the table’s read on potential assassins and protect Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Took calculated risks, like joining the failed Mission 3 team in a way that didn’t immediately out her as evil, indicating she’s comfortable playing close to the center of trust. Her assassin guess on Diana suggests she was misreading some of the late-game table talk and Merlin signals.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very steady, trustworthy game, consistently ending up on successful teams and not drawing much suspicion. His low-drama style made him an anchor for good, though it also made him a potential soft target for evil to hide behind.
player_observations.Diana: Was frequently in the mission core and projected a generally good-aligned vibe, enough that even the assassin mistook her for Merlin. She handled the Mission 3 fail suspicion reasonably well, suggesting she can absorb pressure without overreacting.
player_observations.Eve: Did an excellent job as Merlin, guiding team selections toward mostly clean missions while not being so obvious that the assassin locked onto her. Her balance of influence and subtlety was strong, especially given that the final assassin guess missed her.
player_observations.Frank: Played quietly and didn’t force the game’s direction, which allowed him to blend in as evil without being heavily scrutinized. His lower-profile approach likely helped keep suspicion away from the actual evil core.
player_observations.Grace: Her Percival play seemed to lean toward trusting Eve correctly, which helped reinforce good’s coordination and mission stability. She projected a generally pro-good presence without being overly showy, supporting Merlin’s cover.
player_observations.Henry: Stayed just far enough from the mission spotlight that his Mordred role didn’t attract heavy suspicion, using partial distance from key teams to avoid blame. His subtle positioning showed comfort with playing a hidden, supportive evil role rather than a loud disruptor.
player_observations.Iris: Flew under the radar for much of the game, contributing without sharply steering decisions, which made her read as mildly good but not central. This quiet style meant she neither greatly helped nor hurt the deduction process, keeping her impact modest but solidly non-threatening.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission, helped establish a strong trust core with Bob and Charlie, and my participation on the failed Mission 3 didn’t overly compromise the team’s confidence in me. I could improve by being more vocal in pushing structured logic after the fail on Mission 3 to better narrow down suspects and more actively protect Eve by diverting suspicion toward more plausible Merlin candidates.

player_observations.Alice: Took the clean double-success opening and used Mission 3 to inject doubt in a subtle way, blending in well before revealing as the assassin. Likely to prefer mid-game disruption over early chaos, which makes her dangerous when missions start off smoothly.
player_observations.Bob: Played very consistently with a trustworthy, straightforward good style, anchoring early mission success. Seems comfortable repeating known-good teams and not overcomplicating deductions, which is stabilizing but could be exploitable by sophisticated evils.
player_observations.Charlie: Formed a strong early trust triangle and seemed to value logical continuity in team selections. His pattern suggests he’s methodical and risk-averse, which is great for good but might make him slightly predictable for evil to plan around.
player_observations.Eve: Did an excellent job as Merlin by not oversteering team choices or telegraphing special knowledge too strongly, especially after the Mission 3 fail. Her willingness to join a large Mission 4 team without over-justifying it helped her stay just ambiguous enough to dodge the assassin.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed low-impact enough that his Morgana presence didn’t loudly stand out, which allowed good to rely more on team track records than on loud table talk. Likely prefers a quieter evil style that leans on subtle influence rather than bold misdirection.
player_observations.Grace: Played a solid supportive role, accepting good configurations and not forcing unnecessary conflict, which fit well with her Percival role. Her restraint in hard-clearing anyone publicly helped avoid overexposing Merlin, showing good role awareness.
player_observations.Henry: As Mordred, blended reasonably into the background of team selections, avoiding big attention spikes that could attract Merlin-protective logic from good. Seems to favor a patient, less confrontational evil approach, waiting for structural opportunities like the Mission 3 fail.
player_observations.Iris: Had limited direct mission impact this game but did not generate major suspicion, suggesting a more cautious, low-profile good playstyle. Likely to be more of a supporting voice than a leading force in table deductions unless strongly prompted.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-key enough that the assassin was pulled toward Diana, while still nudging teams in the right direction, especially on Mission 4 where I backed a fully clean team. I could improve by more systematically masking my support for known-goods earlier in the game, so my late-game confidence spike is less noticeable.

player_observations.Alice: Willing to fail late rather than early, which made you look more cautious and less obvious as the assassin; you blended well on the first two missions.
player_observations.Bob: Consistent, straightforward team choices and voting patterns that felt very ‘by the book’ good, which made you trustworthy pretty early on.
player_observations.Charlie: Played in a logically open way, asking reasonable questions and building trust gradually; your willingness to repeat similar cores helped confirm you as good.
player_observations.Diana: You looked like a strong, confident good leader, which unfortunately also made you an appealing Merlin target; your involvement in the failed mission created just enough ambiguity to misdirect the assassin.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively quiet and tried to ride along with consensus, a classic subtle-evil approach that avoided drawing big suspicion but also didn’t strongly drive the narrative.
player_observations.Grace: Your behavior matched a cautious information-role: you defended some players without overcommitting and helped stabilize team choices, hinting at Percival without fully outing yourself.
player_observations.Henry: You remained in the background and avoided critical leadership spots, which kept you off the radar but also limited your ability to steer suspicion away from your teammates.
player_observations.Iris: Low-impact, low-controversy presence: you didn’t push hard theories, which helped you avoid suspicion but also meant you weren’t a major driver of table reads.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated reasonably well with the evil team by staying mostly low-key and letting others drive team selections, which helped keep suspicion off me for most of the game. However, I didn’t do enough to create plausible Merlin candidates beyond Eve, and I should have been more proactive in muddying the waters for Percival and pushing alternative reads that could have led the assassin away from Eve.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to play cautiously and avoided drawing attention, which helped her survive to the assassin phase without being too heavily suspected. Could perhaps have done more overt misdirection late-game to steer the kill toward a stronger decoy Merlin.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as steady and reliable, and his repeated inclusion on early mission teams built a lot of trust around him. He didn’t overtalk, which made his presence on teams feel safe and uncontroversial.
player_observations.Charlie: Played as a consistent, logic-driven voice who helped stabilize team discussions. Their calm reasoning style made them look reliably good and helped support the success of early missions without seeming flashy or Merlin-like.
player_observations.Diana: Got positioned as a key core member of teams and looked quite trustworthy for most of the game. The failed mission with her on it created some ambiguity, but she still managed to avoid being a strong Merlin candidate in the end.
player_observations.Eve: Did a strong job as Merlin by nudging team choices in the right direction without appearing too controlling. Her subtle influence didn’t flag her as obviously special, which ultimately protected her from the assassin’s guess.
player_observations.Grace: Played a very perceptive, watchful game and often tracked mission compositions and voting patterns closely. As Percival, she seemed careful not to out her information too blatantly, which kept evil from easily identifying who she was.
player_observations.Henry: Stayed relatively under the radar, which as Mordred is valuable since it limits Merlin’s ability to call you out directly with confidence in social reads. Could potentially have applied more pressure in discussions to create confusion about where the evil team was located.
player_observations.Iris: Took a more low-key good role, contributing enough to not look checked out but not dominating conversations. This quieter presence made it harder for evil to get clear reads or exploit her, and she fit into good teams without much objection.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly kept strong townreads on Bob, Charlie, and Diana through the game and treated Eve and (to a lesser extent) Diana as the likely Merlin/Morgana pair, which helped protect the real Merlin enough for the Assassin to miss. I could improve by being clearer and more vocal near the end about why I leaned Eve over Diana as Merlin, to better steer good players’ perceptions without overexposing Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: You played fairly quietly but used Mission 3 to get a needed fail in a way that still left some ambiguity, which is solid Assassin play. However, your late-game Merlin read on Diana suggested you were perhaps overfocusing on mission leadership patterns rather than who subtly directed team selections.
player_observations.Bob: You came across consistently village-aligned with steady, low-drama logic, which made it easy to trust you after the first successful mission. Your willingness to repeat cores and not overreact to the Mission 3 fail was very pro-good and helped stabilize team building.
player_observations.Charlie: You felt methodical and open, often aligning with sensible team choices without pushing too hard to control outcomes, which made you a reliable anchor for good. Your calm reactions to mission results made you appear like a natural inclusion on most late teams.
player_observations.Diana: You were very central to the game—a frequent team pick and a plausible Merlin candidate—yet you stayed just ambiguous enough that evil could credibly shoot you. Your response to the failed Mission 3 was measured and cooperative, which kept you trusted despite being on the failing team.
player_observations.Eve: You played an excellent low-key Merlin game: your influence on team composition—especially Mission 4—felt gently guiding rather than forceful, which helped hide you. You let others front the loud logic while you nudged toward strong good cores, which clearly paid off when the Assassin missed.
player_observations.Frank: Your presence felt more reactive than driving, which is a reasonable Morgana approach when Merlin isn’t being obvious. You didn’t manage to fully sell yourself as the competing Merlin candidate, though, which made it easier for me to narrow the Merlin/Morgana pair away from you.
player_observations.Henry: You stayed in the shadows a bit too much for Mordred, which kept suspicion low but also limited your ability to meaningfully steer team choices. A bit more assertive but 'reasoned' disagreement on team compositions might have created more confusion among the good players.
player_observations.Iris: Your playstyle felt cooperative and trusting, which supported the emerging good core without muddying the waters too much. Even though you weren’t central to the critical missions, your lack of wild accusations helped maintain a calm environment that favored good’s information use.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as Mordred and didn't attract strong suspicion, but I also failed to meaningfully steer team selections or discussion away from Merlin. I need to be more proactive in shaping the narrative, pushing subtle suspicion onto non-Merlin players, and coordinating more clearly with my fellow evil roles about where the assassin shot should go.

player_observations.Alice: Played assassin cautiously and waited for more information rather than forcing an early narrative, but could refine endgame logic to weigh Eve’s quiet influence more heavily.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as consistently trustworthy and steady, contributing just enough reasoning without overexplaining, which helped him stay uncontroversial on multiple missions.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very cooperative, logic-forward style that made them a natural inclusion on teams and helped reinforce trust in the early successful missions.
player_observations.Diana: Looked very mission-focused and straightforward, which made the failed Mission 3 an effective red herring that drew some late suspicion despite her generally clean image.
player_observations.Eve: Did an excellent job as Merlin by guiding team selections subtly and avoiding overtly strong pushes that would reveal her, especially around Mission 4’s composition.
player_observations.Frank: As Morgana, stayed relatively low-key and didn’t overclaim information, but could perhaps lean harder into mimicking Merlin-like guidance to create more confusion for Percival.
player_observations.Grace: Played Percival carefully, following and reinforcing Eve’s leads without making it obvious whom she trusted most, which helped protect Merlin through to the assassin phase.
player_observations.Iris: Maintained a low-profile good playstyle, not driving major decisions but also not generating much suspicion, which kept the table’s focus on more vocal players.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in my reads and didn’t introduce much confusion, which helped me blend into the trustworthy majority once missions 1 and 2 were clean. I could improve by being more vocal about structured reasoning (who looks evil and why) so that Merlin and Percival have clearer cover and the evil team has a harder time finding the power roles.

player_observations.Alice: Played a relatively low-key but well-timed evil game, taking her shot on Mission 3 in a way that didn’t immediately clear or condemn any single player. Her assassin guess on Diana suggests she was misled by Eve’s subtlety and perhaps overestimated how much Diana was steering the table.
player_observations.Bob: Came off very reliably good, especially with the clean early missions that he was on, which anchored a lot of trust around him. His willingness to repeat similar cores on teams without overselling his reads made him look naturally towny rather than performative.
player_observations.Charlie: Maintained a calm, collaborative presence and fit neatly into the ‘trusted core’ after consecutive successful missions. He seemed comfortable taking solid but not flashy positions, which made him feel like a stabilizer rather than someone trying to force outcomes.
player_observations.Diana: Ended up in a suspicious spot after the failed Mission 3 but handled it with enough composure that the assassin still targeted her as Merlin. Her style drew some attention—she looked thoughtful and engaged in team discussions, which made her a believable candidate for a power role.
player_observations.Eve: Did an excellent job as Merlin, signaling suspicion on the right people without loudly hard-pushing them, which preserved her cover. Her ability to orchestrate or endorse the successful mission 4 team while not standing out too much was key to both the win and the assassin miss.
player_observations.Frank: As Morgana, he kept a relatively low profile and didn’t overclaim insight, which helped maintain ambiguity between him and Merlin. His subtle presence contributed to making the evil team composition less obvious even though they couldn’t ultimately convert that into a correct assassination.
player_observations.Grace: Played a solid Percival game by visibly engaging with the ‘who’s Merlin’ puzzle but not outing her conclusions too directly. She followed Eve’s lead in a way that supported good missions while still leaving enough uncertainty that evil couldn’t be sure who the real Merlin was.
player_observations.Henry: As Mordred, he stayed in the background enough that he never became a prime suspect or a clear towncore member, keeping him in a gray area. His conservative approach reduced immediate heat on him, but it also meant he didn’t strongly shape mission teams in evil’s favor.
